[Find my Nearest](https://apps.wigan.gov.uk/MyNeighbourhood "Find my nearest") 
You can use your postcode to find your nearest **schools**, **hospitals**, **libraries, council services** and more.

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/Accessibility statement for www.wigan.gov.uk

# Accessibility statement for www.wigan.gov.uk

This website is run by Wigan Council. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website on a variety of devices.

For example, that means you should be able to:

* Change colours, contrast levels and fonts
* Zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
* Navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
* Navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
* Listen to most of the website using a screen reader.

We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.

[AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability (external link)](https://mcmw.abilitynet.org.uk/).

## How accessible this website is

We know some parts of this website aren’t fully accessible:

* Most older PDFs and other documents aren’t fully accessible to screen reader software
* Some of our online forms are difficult to navigate using just a keyboard
* Content and functionality provided by third party suppliers is not fully accessible
* Live video streams do not have captions
* Maps are not accessible
* Third party content.

## Feedback and contact information

If you need any information on this website in a different format, you can:

* [Request information in other formats](/Accessibility-feedback.aspx "Accessibility feedback").

We’ll consider your request and get back to you in 10 working days.

## Reporting accessibility problems with this website

We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website, so if you have identified any accessibility issues or if you think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, you can:

* [Report accessibility problems](/Accessibility-feedback.aspx "Accessibility feedback").

## Enforcement procedure

The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing [The Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2\) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’) (external link)](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2018/952/contents/made). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, you can  [contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS) (external link)](https://www.equalityadvisoryservice.com/).

## Technical information about this website’s accessibility

Wigan Council is committed to making its website accessible, in accordance with [The Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2\) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (external link)](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2018/952/contents/made).

This website is partially compliant with the [Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2\.1 (external link)](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/) AA standard, due to the non\-compliance's and exemptions listed below.

## Non accessible content

The content listed below is non\-accessible for the following reasons:

## Non compliance with the accessibility regulations

### PDFs and other documents

Most of our old PDFs and downloadable documents require improved title descriptions, can be difficult to navigate due to poor use of bookmarks, are not fully machine readable and are untagged. This fails WCAG 2\.1 success criterion 1\.1\.1, 1\.3\.1, 2\.4\.2, 2\.4\.5 and 3\.1\.1\.

We are prioritising downloaded documents which are essential to providing our services. We use a variety of accessibility tools to monitor our downloadable PDFs, which allow us to apply fixes regularly. We use Adobe Pro’s accessibility checker and Microsoft Office accessibility checkers to improve accessibility.

We’ve also been archiving out of date documents and ensuring new documents meet the accessibility standards, or the content is available in HTML format.

Our work to ensure that all essential downloadable files meet accessibility regulations is continuing and we aim to complete the review by April 2025\.

### Third party applications

We have completed accessibility reports on existing third party applications and have been working with our suppliers to improve accessibility.

The following services do not currently meet accessibility standards:

* [MyAccount services](/MyAccount/My-Account.aspx "MyAccount") \- we launched our new MyAccount on 1st April 2021\. We have a full programme of works to review and replace third party applications which sit within MyAccount and have a business plan of 3 years to implement these changes. Any new online processes will be built to meet the required accessibility standards
* [Borough Life](/Council/Borough-Life/BoroughLife.aspx "Borough Life") \- an accessible version of the PDF magazine containing the main articles is now available in the form of Borough Life Plus
* When making payment for services, the text 'Search' does not have sufficient colour contrast against the background.  This fails WACG 2\.1 criterion 1\.4\.3\.  We have instructed our provider to make a change and aim to complete the change by the end of December 2024\.
* For security reasons, a timeout feature is added to some of our forms. This fails WACG 2\.2\.1 and 2\.2\.6\. We have requested that our provider make a change so that users are warned and given the option to extend the time to prevent any data loss. We aim to resolve the issue by end of December 2024\.

### Online forms

Some of our online forms are provided by third party suppliers and are not fully operable through a keyboard or mobile device. This doesn’t meet WCAG 2\.1 success criterion 2\.1\.1\. We have purchased a new form package and will be replacing all forms which do not meet accessibility standards. A review is underway and we aim to complete this work by April 2025\.

## Content that’s not within the scope of the accessibility regulations

### PDFs and other documents

Many of our older PDFs and other documents don’t meet accessibility standards. For example, they may not be structured in a way that makes them accessible to a screen reader. This doesn’t meet WCAG 2\.1 success criterion 4\.1\.2\.

The accessibility regulations [don’t require us to fix PDFs or other documents published before 23rd September 2018 (external link)](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2018/952/regulation/4/made) if they’re not essential to providing our services.

### Live video streams

Live video streams do not have captions. The accessibility regulations don’t require us to add captions to live video streams.

### Maps

It is not possible to make maps accessible, but we will provide essential information in an accessible format.

### Third party content

Within Our Town Directory we have content which is provided to us by third party organisations within the community. Whilst we advise on best practice, we have not paid for or developed the content ourselves and therefore the content is within someone else’s control.

## Preparation of this accessibility statement

This statement was prepared on 23rd September 2019\. It was last reviewed on 4 June 2024\.

This website is regularly tested against WACG 2\.1 criterion using 3 automated testing tools:

* Sitemorse scans our site monthly. Their approach to testing is available on the [Sitemorse assessments criteria (external link)](https://sitemorse.com/assessment-categories/accessibility) and results are published on the [Sitemorse Index for local government (external link)](https://sitemorse.com/index/)
* Silktide scans our site monthly. Their approach to testing and our results is available on [Wigan Council’s Silktide’s index (external link)](https://index.silktide.com/category/council-uk)
* Siteimprove re\-scans the whole of our site on a weekly basis, so that we can apply identified fixes on a weekly basis. Their approach to testing is available on the Siteimprove website \- [see Siteimprove website accessibility checker (external link)](https://www.siteimprove.com/toolkit/accessibility-checker/).

We monitor the result on a weekly basis and fix identified issues applying WCAG 2\.1 AA standards, aiming for AAA where possible.

We do a combination of automated and manual testing. Manual testing is undertaken before any new live content goes live and forms part of any pre go live checks.

Our last manual audit of the site for historic content took place in August 2021\.

Displaying 1 to 1 of 1

## [Zoos](/Business/Licensing-Permits-Registrations/Animals/zoos.aspx "Zoos")

 You need a licence to run a zoo and a fee must be paid when you make your application. You must give us at least two months advance notice of your intention to apply for a licence.

# Free weekend parking

![Free weekend parking](/Images/Resident/Parking,-roads-and-travel/Free-parking.png)
We offer free weekend parking on council owned town centre car parks in Wigan and Leigh.  

**Please note:**

* Roadside parking not covered in these offers.
* Loire Drive car parks are excluded from these offers.
* The Grand Arcade is not a council owned car park.

## Top tasks

 ## In this section

* [Wigan car parks](/Resident/Parking-Roads-Travel/Parking/Car-parks-and-charges/Wigan-car-parks.aspx "Go to Wigan car parks from here")

* [Car park and permit charges](/Resident/Parking-Roads-Travel/Parking/Car-parks-and-charges/Car-park-and-permit-charges.aspx "Go to Car park and permit charges from here")

Displaying 1 to 8 of 8

## [Value for Money](/Council/Performance-and-Spending/Value-for-Money.aspx "Value for Money")

 We recognise our duty of best value and our responsibility to achieve value for money in service delivery. We will seek to incorporate value for money principles in delivering services by taking account of costs, quality of services and the local context.

## [Vehicle Eligibility](/Business/Licensing-Permits-Registrations/Taxi-and-Private-Hire/Vehicle-Eligibility.aspx "Vehicle Eligibility")

 Applicants are advised to read through and familiarise themselves with the below information, including the conditions which are attached to all vehicle licences, prior to submitting an application Failure to do so could lead to an application being rejected or refused.

## [Vehicles](/Business/Licensing-Permits-Registrations/Taxi-and-Private-Hire/Vehicles/Vehicles.aspx "Vehicles")

 Information and guidance on Hackney Carriage and Private Hire vehicles.

## [Venues](/Resident/Births-Marriage-Deaths/Marriages-and-Civil-Partnerships/Ceremony-venues.aspx "Venues")

 A range of beautiful locations to have your wedding day with us, or hold other ceremonies in the borough.

## [Vocational skills and qualifications](/Resident/Jobs-Careers/Adult-Learning/Vocational-skills-and-qualifications.aspx "Vocational skills and qualifications")

 We have several courses that provide learners with the opportunity to develop their skills and achieve a qualification to prepare for further study or to move into a paid role.

## [Volunteer with us](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Autism-friendly/Volunteer-with-us.aspx "Volunteer with us")

 We're looking for like\-minded people who share our passion to support us with the Autism Friends campaign by either becoming an Autism Friends Champion or Lead to help promote the understanding and acceptance of autism.

## [Volunteering](/Council/The-Deal/Volunteering/index.aspx "Volunteering")

 Volunteering opportunities in the areas of culture and leisure, health, people and the community, schools and the environment.

## [Voter ID](/Council/Voting-and-Elections/Voter-ID.aspx "Voter ID")

 The Government has brought in new regulations about Voter ID, this includes the acceptable types of photo ID and how you can apply for a "Voter Authority Certificate" if you don't have one of the types listed below.

# Local Offer

[Local Offer Menu](#)
* [About Local Offer](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/About-Local-Offer.aspx "About Local Offer")
* [Parent / Carer](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/Parent/index.aspx "I'm a Parent / Carer")
* [Young Person](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/Young-Person/index.aspx "I'm a Young Person")

Search

Local Offer

[![Family Hubs banner](/Images/Resident/Education/Family-Hubs-banner.jpg)](/Resident/Education/Family-Hubs/index.aspx "Family Hubs")

## Welcome to the SEND Local Offer for Wigan

* [I'm a Parent / Carer](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/Parent/index.aspx "I'm a parent")
* [I'm a Young Person](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/Young-Person/index.aspx "I'm a young person")
* [I'm a Professional](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/Professional/Index.aspx "I'm a professional")

## Latest news

[News and updates](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/SEND-news.aspx "SEND news")
View the latest news, information, events and opportunities for children and young people with SEND in the Wigan Borough.

[Wigan PCF on Twitter](https://twitter.com/WiganPCF "Wigan PCF on Twitter")
Follow Wigan Parent Carer Forum to find out about sessions, events and opportunities for parent carers of children with additional needs.

## Get involved

* [Get in touch](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/SEND-contact.aspx "SEND Local Offer")
* [Give us your feedback](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/SEND-feedback.aspx "Give us your feedback")
* [Become a SEND Champion](/Resident/Education/Special-Educational-Needs-and-Disability/Local-Offer/SEND-champions.aspx "SEND Champion")

**Join Wigan Parent Carer Forum**

An online community to provide a safe environment for parent carers to share information.

* [Parent Carer Forum](https://www.wiganpcf.org.uk/ "Visit Parent Carer Forum")
* [Parent Carer on Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/wiganparentforum "Visit Parent Carer on Facebook")

![parent-carer-logo](/SiteElements/Images/Local-Offer/parent-carer-logo.png)

## Directories of services

[Our Town Directory](https://directory.wigan.gov.uk/kb5/wigan/fsd/home.page "Our Town DIrectory")
Find childcare options in Wigan Borough to meet your needs, and services for children with SEND.

[LINC2](/LINC2/index.aspx "Visit LINC 2 website")
Find activities for young people and check out survival guide featuring advice from young people.

}

 content:'(MS Excel Document, '
}

 content:'(CSV File Document, '
}

 content:')'
}

/\*Retina graphics!\*/
@media only screen and (\-webkit\-min\-device\-pixel\-ratio: 1\.5\),
 only screen and (min\-\-moz\-device\-pixel\-ratio: 1\.5\),
 only screen and (min\-device\-pixel\-ratio: 1\.5\){

 \#fancybox\-loading, .fancybox\-close, .fancybox\-prev span, .fancybox\-next span {
 background: url('/SiteElements/Images/fancybox\-sprite.png');
 background\-size: 44px 152px; /\*The size of the normal image, half the size of the hi\-res image\*/
 }

 \#fancybox\-loading div {
 background: url('/SiteElements/Images/fancybox\-loading@2x.gif');
 background\-size: 24px 24px; /\*The size of the normal image, half the size of the hi\-res image\*/
 }
}

.fancybox\-nav {
 width: 60px; 
}

 margin:0!important;
 height:50px;

 /\* IE9 SVG, needs conditional override of 'filter' to 'none' \*/

background: \-webkit\-gradient(linear, left top, left bottom, color\-stop(76%,rgba(240,243,250,1\)), color\-stop(100%,rgba(255,255,255,0\))); /\* Chrome,Safari4\+ \*/

background: \-o\-linear\-gradient(top, rgba(240,243,250,1\) 76%,rgba(255,255,255,0\) 100%); /\* Opera 11\.10\+ \*/

background: linear\-gradient(to bottom, rgba(240,243,250,1\) 76%,rgba(255,255,255,0\) 100%); /\* W3C \*/
filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient( startColorstr\='\#f0f3fa', endColorstr\='\#00ffffff',GradientType\=0 ); /\* IE6\-8 \*/

}

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Borough news](/News/Borough-news.aspx "Go to Borough news from here")/[Articles](/News/Articles/News.aspx "Go to Articles from here")/RL legend Phil calls on Wiganers to be Warriors in fight against dementia

# RL legend Phil calls on Wiganers to be Warriors in fight against dementia

## RL legend Phil calls on Wiganers to be Warriors in fight against dementia

![Phil Clarke with Councillors Chris Ready (left) and Lawrence Hunt (right) at Wigan Hall](/CachedImage.axd?ImageName=%2fImages%2fNews%2f2024%2fPhil-Clarke-with-Councillors-Chris-Ready-left-and-Lawrence-Hunt-right-at-Wigan-Hall.jpeg&ImageWidth=400&ImageHeight=400)Memory Walk special guest Phil Clarke with Councillor Chris Ready and Councillor Lawrence Hunt at Wigan Hall

Rugby league legend Phil Clarke is urging Wiganers to tackle dementia by signing up for this year’s Be Well Memory Walk.

The former Wigan Warriors star and ex\-Sky TV pundit will be the special guest at the annual Alzheimer’s Society fundraiser at Haigh Woodland Park on Sunday 22 September (11am).

Phil, who won five Challenge Cups and two World Club Challenges with the Warriors, has been a long\-standing champion of the Memory Walk having struck up a friendship with organiser Tracy Lamb.

Tracy lost her dad George to dementia in 2021 and, like her, Phil has his own personal motivation for taking part.

He explained: “I first got involved because Tracy asked me – and, once you’ve met her, you can’t say no! She’s got so much enthusiasm for life and for this Memory Walk, because of what it means to her.

“I’ve had family friends who have died sadly through dementia and suffered seriously towards the end, so I wanted to get involved and show my support.

“The Alzheimer’s Society is a very important charity so any money we can raise for them helps. With an ever\-ageing population, the problem is only going to get worse unless we address it.

“I’ve met so many nice people at the Memory Walk and I like the fact that it’s a really friendly atmosphere; all the people are really kind and positive and that appeals to me.

“I think for a lot of people the Memory Walk is an opportunity to come together, almost as an anniversary walk for the ones they’ve loved, and share some happy memories of the ones who are no longer with us.”

This month’s event is the second Be Well Memory Walk of 2024, following on from a first\-ever Alzheimer's Society fundraiser at Pennington Flash back in June.

Organisers hope to top the £4,000 figure raised last year – with locals urged to donate and raise money by getting friends and family to sponsor them.

Once again there are two different walks to choose from; a short accessible stroll around the park and walled gardens, or an hour\-long 3km/2 mile walk taking in the surrounding area.

There will also be live music from the Happy Pluckers ukelele band, forget\-me\-not facepainting and a special orienteering challenge for children.

Councillor Chris Ready, Wigan Council’s portfolio holder for communities and neighbourhoods, said: “The Memory Walk isn’t just about raising funds for an incredible cause, it’s also about coming together as a community and sharing special stories and memories of loved ones we’ve lost to this cruel disease.

“The event at Haigh Woodland Park is always such a positive, feel\-good family occasion. I’d like to thank Phil Clarke for once again showing his support and I hope as many people as possible are able to come along and join us as we walk for a world without dementia.”

The Memory Walk is free to join and you can register to take part online or on the day. Everybody who registers in advance will be guaranteed a certificate, while those who register and make a donation of £10 or more will also receive a branded tote bag as a special thank you.

Sponsorship forms are also available to download from the official Be Well Memory Walk web page.

To sign up or for more information, visit [Be Well Memory Walk (external link)](https://bewellwigan.org/memorywalk/ "Memory walk").

 Posted on Wednesday 4th September 2024

# Greenheart

![Greenheart logo](/Images/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/gh-logo.gif)

![Greenheart slider - Flashes](/Images/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/slider/gh-slider-flashes.jpg)![Greenheart slider - Haigh Hall](/Images/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/slider/gh-slider-haighhall.jpg)![Greenheart slider - Pennington](/Images/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/slider/gh-slider-pennington.jpg)

* [About GreenheartFrom Leigh all the way up to Haigh Woodland Park, there is so much to see and discover](/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/About-Greenheart.aspx)
* [Greenheart on the mapExplore Wigan's Greenheart on our handy map and learn more about the area](/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/Greenheart-on-the-Map.aspx)
* [Nature ReservesEnabling residents and visitors to enjoy rich wildlife and diverse habitats](/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/LNR.aspx)
* [Sites of special interestAreas of land and water protected by law for their unique wildlife and geology](/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/SSSI/Index.aspx)
* [Useful linksFind further information with our partner agencies](/Resident/Leisure/Greenheart/Contact-us.aspx)
 * [Heritage, Nature and People projectSetting out to link our natural and built heritage to health and wellbeing through outdoor activities](/Council/Projects/Haigh-Project/Index.aspx)

## Find my Nearest

[Find my Nearest](https://apps.wigan.gov.uk/MyNeighbourhood "Find my nearest") 
You can use your postcode to find your nearest **schools**, **hospitals**, **libraries, council services** and more.

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Resident](/Resident/index.aspx "Go to Resident from here")/[Environmental problems](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Environmental-Problems.aspx "Go to Environmental problems from here")/[Neighbourhood nuisance](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Neighbourhood-nuisance/Index.aspx "Go to Neighbourhood nuisance from here")/Neighbourhood nuisance

# Neighbourhood nuisance

This information relates to domestic properties and farm land only. If your problem concerns a business, including pubs and clubs please see our [commercial pollution pages.](/Business/Environmental-Health/Pollution/index.aspx "Pollution")

Anti\-social behaviour (ASB) includes a wide range of unacceptable behaviour that affects the quality of life for residents and others living or working in the community. This behaviour is often a criminal offence and therefore a matter for the Police.

However, we often receive complaints about things that are not anti\-social but are more about a different style of living.

* [Find out what is and is not anti\-social behaviour](/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/ASB/Anti-social-behaviour.aspx "Anti-social behaviour (ASB)").

## What is nuisance?

Statutory nuisance is a legal term meaning that the actions of someone else are substantially affecting the reasonable enjoyment of your property. For a matter to be actionable as a nuisance in law it must be a serious and persistent issue \- one\-off events rarely qualify.

Nuisance can be a form of anti\-social behaviour, but often people do not realise that their actions will be negatively affecting others.

For the issue to count as a statutory nuisance, it must do one of the following:

* Unreasonably and substantially interfere with the use or enjoyment of a home or other premises
* Injure health or be likely to injure health.

## Types of nuisance

The most common types of nuisance are:

* [Anti\-social behaviour (ASB)](/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/ASB/Anti-social-behaviour.aspx "Anti-social behaviour (ASB)") \- This includes a wide range of unacceptable behaviour
* [Noise](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Noise/index.aspx "Noise nuisance") \- Equipment such as stereos, a barking dog or DIY work at inappropriate times
* [Smoke and fumes](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Smoke/Index.aspx "Smoke and air pollution") \- Bonfires, chimineas, construction work or DIY
* [Light](/Business/Environmental-Health/Pollution/Artificial-light.aspx "Artificial light") \- A floodlight at a neighbouring property shining directly into your window
* [Unpleasant odours](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Smells/Smells-and-odours.aspx "Smells and odours") \- Very unpleasant smells after a farmer has spread manure on a field (see [agricultural smells](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Smells/Agricultural-smells.aspx "Agricultural smells")) or unpleasant smells coming from a nearby property
* [Rubbish in gardens](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Rubbish-and-Litter/Rubbish-in-gardens.aspx "Rubbish in gardens") \- A large pile of domestic waste in a neighbour's garden or animal fouling that is not being cleaned up regularly in a neighbouring yard.

## What you can do

Before you contact us, we would advise you to discuss the problem with your neighbour, if you feel it's safe to do so. Often, they simply do not realise they are causing a problem. It can create ill feeling in communities if people approach the council directly without talking to their neighbours first.

* [See advice on how to approach a neighbour](/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/ASB/Good-neighbour-guide.aspx "How to be a good neighbour").

However, if the problem continues you can report it to us.

**Before you report it, you should complete a [nuisance diary](/Docs/PDF/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/Anti-social-behaviour/Nuisance-Diary-Sheets.docx "Nuisance Diary Sheets") detailing how and when you are being affected by the issue, especially when dealing with noise and smoke complaints.**

## What we can do

We have a duty to investigate complaints of alleged nuisance. If your problem is being caused by a domestic property, see what steps you can take to report it to us:

* [Anti\-social behaviour (ASB)](/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/ASB/Anti-social-behaviour.aspx "Anti-social behaviour (ASB)")
* [Noise](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Noise/index.aspx "Noise nuisance")
* [Smoke and fumes](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Smoke/Index.aspx "Smoke and air pollution")
* [Light](/Business/Environmental-Health/Pollution/Artificial-light.aspx "Artificial light")
* [Unpleasant odours](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Smells/Smells-and-odours.aspx "Smells and odours")
* [Rubbish in gardens](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Rubbish-and-Litter/Rubbish-in-gardens.aspx "Rubbish in gardens").

If someone fails to deal with a nuisance once they have been formally instructed to do so by the council, they can face prosecution in court and a fine of up to £5000\. In cases of noise nuisance, the council also has the power to seize noise making equipment such as stereos.

All complaints that we receive are confidential and your details will not be disclosed unless we have to take the case to court. We will **NOT** investigate anonymous complaints.

## Taking private action

You may also wish to take formal action at the Magistrate’s Court. We may advise you to do this if after investigating your complaint, we have been unable to gather enough evidence to demonstrate that a statutory nuisance exists.

* Contact the [Wigan and Leigh Citizen Advice Bureau (external link)](https://www.cawb.org.uk/ "Citizens Advice Bureau - Wigan & Leigh") for independent advice.

## Top tasks

### Report it

1. [Report anti\-social behaviour (ASB)](/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/ASB/How-to-report-anti-social-behaviour.aspx "Go to the Report anti-social behaviour (ASB) page")
2. [Report noise nuisance](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Noise/index.aspx "Go to the Report noise nuisance page")
3. [Report smoke and air pollution](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Smoke/Index.aspx "Go to the Report smoke and air pollution page")

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Resident](/Resident/index.aspx "Go to Resident from here")/[Births, marriages and deaths](/Resident/Births-Marriage-Deaths/Births-Marriages-Deaths.aspx "Go to Births, marriages and deaths from here")/Copy Certificates

# Copy Certificates

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

We hold registers for Wigan and Leigh from 1837 to the present day. You can order a copy of the following:

* Birth certificate
* Death certificate
* Marriage or civil partnership certificate.

We can only supply certificates for the records we hold.

## What information do I need to provide?

**Before you apply for a copy certificate**, you will need the following information:

* Your full name, address, daytime telephone number and email in case we need to contact you regarding the request
* The exact date of the registration or for family history purposes a minimum of the year and monthquarter are essential
* The full names of the people involved, where possible, otherwise we can not ensure the correct entry will be issued.

## Family history

If you're tracing your family history you will be able to find reference on the Lancashire BMD website.

* [Visit Lancashire BMD (external link)](https://www.lancashirebmd.org.uk/).

Further help researching your family history can be found at [Wigan Archives and Local Studies](/Resident/Museums-archives/Wigan-Archives/Collections/index.aspx "Archives: Wigan and Leigh collections").

## Ordering marriage certificates

If the request is a marriage certificate, then you must provide the exact place or the name of the church. This is very important for the location of the entry. **We are unable to process certificates that do not include this information**.

If your marriage took place after 4th May 2021 in a religious building, we can only provide certificates once the marriage schedule or document has been returned to us to register the event. If we have not received the marriage schedule or document, we will let you know so you may follow this up with the clergy or authorised person.

## Certificate fees and delivery

Please see below delivery fee options when requesting a copy certificate.

Certificate fees and delivery options
| Priority certificate | £38\.50 per certificate | Your certificate will be ready for collection or will be posted out to you within 24 working hours of receiving your application. Applications received after 12 noon will not be processed until the next working day. If postage is your preferred option, this will be sent by first class post. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Standard certificate | £12\.50 per certificate | Standard delivery certificates will be **issued within 15 working days (second class)**. **Second class delivery is included in the fee**. We do not accept any liability for items once they are in the hands of the postal service |

**Please note** \- Priority certificates are sent first class and are signed for. Signed for delivery has the same delivery timescale as standard first class post but has the added security of proof of delivery including a signature from the receiver. You can check online or on your mobile if your item has not been delivered or is delayed. Royal Mail provide compensation cover up to £50 for loss or damage \- [visit the Royal Mail website for further details (external link)](https://www.royalmail.com/retail-compensation-policy-damage).

## How to order

* [Order a copy certificate](https://registrars.wigan.gov.uk/Agenda/onlinebookings/copycertificate.html?pg=31d536a4-73ab-47f9-b4a5-c8f8ab9c27fb "Order a copy certificate")

**All fees are payable by debit or credit card when you make your order**.

## Top tasks

### Top Task

1. [Order a copy certificate](https://registrars.wigan.gov.uk/Agenda/onlinebookings/copycertificate.html?pg=31d536a4-73ab-47f9-b4a5-c8f8ab9c27fb "Go to the Order a copy certificate page")

* [Address](/Contacts/Wigan-and-Leigh-Register-office-no-tel.aspx#ContactAddress)

# Pay a council bill/fine

* [View a list of the ways you can pay for different services](/Pay-for-it/Payment-options-by-service.aspx "Payment options by service").

## Internet

* [Pay your bill/fine online](https://ip.e-paycapita.com/AIP/itemSelectionPage.do?link=showItemSelectionPage&siteId=277&languageCode=EN&source=AIP "Pay a Bill Online")

## Telephone

* [Pay your bill over the phone](/Pay-for-it/PayingaBill.aspx "Pay a Bill by Telephone")

## Direct Debit

* [Set up a Direct Debit](/Pay-for-it/Council-invoices/Setup-direct-debit.aspx "Set up a Direct Debit")

## Bank transfer

To pay your bill via telephone or online banking, or by standing order with your bank you will need our bank details:

* Our bank account number is: 63553698
* Our sort code is: 20\-55\-58
* You **MUST** quote your **billing reference** shown on the front of your bill as the reference for your payment (or we won't be able to allocate it to your specific bill and it may show as unpaid).

What is my billing reference?
| Bill type | Starts with | Number of digits |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Parking | 1 | 9 |
| Council Tax | 4 | 12 |
| Council Tax Internal Enforcement | 3 | 9 |
| Business rates | 5 | 12 |
| Housing rents | 8 | 9 |
| Council invoices | 7 or 9 | 11 |

## Chip and PIN

You can also pay your bill with a debit or credit card using chip and PIN machines at any [Life Centre](/Council/Contact-us/Life-Centres/index.aspx "Life Centres").

Please note you will not be able to pay your Council Tax bill by cash at any of our offices. Please use your local Post Office or PayPoint outlet to pay by cash.

## Post Office and PayPoint

You can pay your bill by cash, debit card or credit card at any Post Office or by cash at any PayPoint outlet nationwide. You will need a bill with a barcode on it to pay. If you already have one of these simply take it along and make the payment.

## Corporate debt policy

The council has a [corporate debt policy](/Docs/PDF/Council/Performance-and-Spending/CorporateDebtPolicy.pdf "CorporateDebtPolicy.pdf") governing the treatment of debt which provides information and advice to customers who may be experiencing problems.

## Top tasks

### Pay for it

1. [Pay a Bill Online](https://ip.e-paycapita.com/AIP/itemSelectionPage.do?link=showItemSelectionPage&siteId=277&languageCode=EN&source=AIP "Go to the Pay a Bill Online page")

# Accessibility

## Sitemorse Index result \- Top 10 Site Q2 2024

Wigan Council website has been awarded a top 10 place for UK Local Government sites for the second quarter of 2024 from Sitemorse.

## Standards

To make sure that we meet the highest standards of access, we actively test and modify our pages to meet the required government level of accessibility, tested against the Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) recommendations as published by the [World Wide Web Consortium (external link)](https://www.w3.org/).

* [See our accessibility statement to find out more about our web standards](/SitePages/Accessibility-statement.aspx "Accessibility statement").

Occasionally, where we have to use external third\-party applications, those pages may not pass all accessibility checks.

## Increase the font size on your browser

If you need to increase the size of the text on the screen your internet browser can do that for you.

* Simply hold down the Ctrl button and click the plus sign (\+) to increase and the minus sign (\-) to decrease.

The BBC have lots of other advice for [making the web easier to use (external link)](https://www.bbc.co.uk/accessibility/).

## Deaf Support Service for Wigan Deaf Community

We work with Topp Language Solutions to provide a remote text, email and video interpreter service for residents with a hearing impairment, available from **8am to 6pm, Monday to Friday**.

To access the service, you will need to:

* Be a person who is deaf / BSL user
* Have a problem you need support with
* Live in Wigan Borough

Text or email our friendly team with a brief description of your issue and we’ll get you the support you need.

* Text 07410 380 366
* Email [hello@topplanguagesolutions.co.uk](mailto:hello@topplanguagesolutions.co.uk)

## Useful websites

* [AbilityNet (external link)](https://mcmw.abilitynet.org.uk/) \- helping disabled people use digital technology at work, at home or in education
* [BBC My Web, My Way (external link)](https://www.bbc.co.uk/accessibility/) \- explains the many ways you can change your browser, computer, keyboard and mouse settings to make the web more accessible for you
* [W3C Web Accessibility Initiative (external link)](https://www.w3.org/WAI/) \- the W3C is the internationally accepted authority on web standards
* [Adobe Accessibility Resource Center (external link)](https://helpx.adobe.com/uk/acrobat/using/create-verify-pdf-accessibility.html) \- accessibility tools for working with PDF files
* [Seeing AI (external link)](https://www.seeingai.com/) \- Seeing AI is a free app that narrates the world for blind and low vision people right from your mobile device. It supports individuals with a variety of daily tasks such as reading mail, identifying everyday products, hearing descriptions of photos and more
* [Be My Eyes / Be My AI (external link)](https://www.bemyeyes.com/download) \- An alternative to Seeing AI, it also allows users to connect and speak to another person who will describe what your device camera can see and answer any questions
* [RNIB technical support (external link)](https://www.rnib.org.uk/living-with-sight-loss/assistive-aids-and-technology/tech-support-and-information/technology-support-and-training/technology-support-we-offer/)
* [NV Access (external link)](https://www.nvaccess.org/download/) \- Free screen reader for PCs running Microsoft Windows 8\.1 and later
* [RNIB hints for accessing websites (external link)](https://www.rnib.org.uk/living-with-sight-loss/independent-living/ "RNIB")
* [Advice for Microsoft users (external link)](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/accessibility/)
* [Advice for Apple users (external link)](https://www.apple.com/accessibility/)
* [Advice for Linux users (external link)](https://opensource.com/life/15/5/accessibility-linux)
* [Henshaws \- hints and tips (external link)](https://www.henshaws.org.uk/hints-and-tips/)

## Contact us

If you or someone you know is experiencing problems accessing our website, or if you have any comments on its accessibility, please [contact the web team](/Website-feedback.aspx "Website feedback") and we will do our very best to help.

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Resident](/Resident/index.aspx "Go to Resident from here")/[Jobs, careers and skills](/Resident/Jobs-Careers/index.aspx "Go to Jobs, careers and skills from here")/Apprenticeships

# Apprenticeships

An apprenticeship is when you're employed to do a real job while studying for a formal qualification. It can last between 1 and 5 years, depending on the level of apprenticeship.

As an apprentice you’ll have a proper job within a proper company, receiving practical ‘on the job’ training to develop job\-specific skills. At the same time, you will also study towards nationally recognised qualifications, and time out of the workplace will be provided to complete this.

Apprenticeships can range from a Level 2 (equivalent to GCSE’s) through to Level 7 (equivalent to a Masters degree) and are available to anyone of working age, not just for young people. There’s scope to undertake an apprenticeship whatever the stage of your career.

## Looking for an apprenticeship?

* [Find an apprenticeship (external link)](https://www.gov.uk/apply-apprenticeship).

## Get help with your application

You can access support when applying for all jobs, including apprenticeships, through the National Careers Service.

Qualified career advisers offer telephone appointments tailored to suit your personal circumstances and can cover the following:

* Securing employment
* CV writing and interview techniques
* Returning to work after a break.

To get support visit the [National Careers Service website (external link)](https://nationalcareers.service.gov.uk/) or call 0161 393 6473\.

## Learn more about apprenticeships

* [Becoming an apprentice (external link)](https://www.gov.uk/become-apprentice)
* [National Apprenticeship Service (external link)](https://www.apprenticeships.gov.uk/#)
* [Greater Manchester Apprenticeship Hub \- advice, support, events and case studies (external link)](https://www.facebook.com/seedifferenthub)
* [Greater Manchester Apprenticeship and Careers Service (GMACS) \- apprenticeship types, application hints and tips, and vacancies](https://bridgegm.co.uk/gmacs)
* [Amazing Apprenticeships \- learn about apprenticeships and vocational education (external link)](https://amazingapprenticeships.com/about-us/).

## Top tasks

 ## In this section

* [Learning, courses and training](/Resident/Jobs-Careers/Adult-community-learning.aspx "Go to Learning, courses and training from here")

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Borough news](/News/Borough-news.aspx "Go to Borough news from here")/[Articles](/News/Articles/News.aspx "Go to Articles from here")/£4\.6m put into pockets of local people thanks to Here for You campaign

# £4\.6m put into pockets of local people thanks to Here for You campaign

## £4\.6m put into pockets of local people thanks to Here for You campaign

A further multi\-million pound milestone has been reached by Wigan Council’s flagship cost\-of\-living crisis support campaign.

More than £4\.6m of previously unclaimed financial support has now been accessed by local people thanks to Here for You.

Launched in 2022, the campaign includes a regular community event schedule helping raise awareness of what benefits residents may be entitled to.

The latest milestone includes 370 peoplewho have claimed £2m of Attendance Allowance and more than 160 pensioners who are now receiving a share of almost £800k through regular Pension Credit payments.

Councillor Susan Gambles, cabinet member for welfare, said: “This additional income has made a life\-changing difference to thousands of households.

“We couldn’t be prouder of our teams’ efforts to raise awareness of what our residents are entitled to and offer expert guidance and support.”

Here for You sees council officers – such as council’s welfare support, housing and community teams  – work closely together to identify opportunities to help residents with cost\-of\-living crisis related issues.

Colin Taylor, who recently attended a Here for You event with his wife, Linda, said: “We didn’t think we qualified for anything and so we were reluctant to go along.

“After only an hour of our time I was walking down the hill in Believe Square with tears running down my face knowing that financially, my life had just changed.

“I feel like a human being with dignity again and I’d recommend anyone who can attends an event, even if you don’t think you’re entitled to anything.

“You aren’t going to come out with less than you went in with.”

A dedicated private space in Wigan Life Centre has opened this month to continue the authority’s efforts and response to the cost\-of\-living crisis, where local people can get expert advice from officers.

This includes tips on money management, energy saving advice and mental health support.

Coun Gambles added: “One of the most fulfilling aspect of this campaign is the impact it has had on the lives of residents like Colin and Linda.

“Hearing many stories like theirs makes us even more determined to continue our efforts, helping our communities through the challenges of the cost\-of\-living crisis.”

To find an event near you, please visit [Help To Claim](/Resident/Benefit-Grants/Here-for-You-Income-Maximisation-events.aspx "Help to claim - Cost of living support events").

 Posted on Tuesday 3rd September 2024

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Resident](/Resident/index.aspx "Go to Resident from here")/[Bins and recycling](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Bins-and-Recycling.aspx "Go to Bins and recycling from here")/Bulky waste and larger household items

# Bulky waste and larger household items

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

![Bulky-Waste-Collection](/Images/Resident/Bins-and-Recycling/Bulky-Waste-Collection.png)

If your unwanted item is in re\-useable condition, why not give it to someone who could use it, whether that’s family, friends, or a community group. A great website to use to donate your items is [freecycle website (external link)](https://www.freecycle.org/). 

You could make money on your unwanted items by selling them locally on a car boot, [Preloved (external link)](https://www.preloved.co.uk/), Facebook or other selling websites and social media.

You can also take items to your [local recycling centre](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Waste-and-Recycling-Centres.aspx "Waste and recycling centres") at no charge. 

Please also consider passing them on to your local charity. We have a variety of charity shops throughout the borough who will accept bric a brac, textiles, furniture, electrical items. Some charities/community groups even upcycle items. For more information, please see the details below. 

Some charities/community groups even upcycle items.

* [See list of charities and community groups who accept donations in Wigan borough.](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Donating-furniture-to-charity.aspx "Donating furniture to charity")

## Bulky Waste Collection Service

Alternatively, if your items are unable to be donated for reuse or upcycling, you can book a bulky waste collection.

By using the Council’s bulky waste collection, you know that you are disposing of your waste responsibly. If you give your waste to someone who is not a licensed waste carrier and it is dumped, you could face a fine or fixed penalty notice\- just as if you dumped it yourself.

### How much does it cost?

* 2 free collections of up to 5 bulky waste items per property in a 12 month period
* Extra collections in a 12 month period will cost £25 for up to five items.

### Booking a collection

* Bookings are available three weeks in advance. There is a limit to the number of large items (like settees) that can be collected per day, due to the size and capacity of our delivery vehicles.
* Booking slots are made available daily on a rolling basis
* A single item is an individual piece, for example a dining table and chairs (up to 4\) is considered two pieces. The same applies to a bed base, headboard and mattress which are taken as three items.
* Please make sure large items such as cupboards and fridges are empty (apart from their own fixtures).

**Please note:**[clinical waste](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Clinical-waste.aspx "Clinical waste") and [trade waste](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Trade-waste.aspx "Trade waste") will not be collected.

### Where do I leave my items?

* Items must be covered and outside by 6:30am on the arranged collection day
* Easily accessible for the crew and any gates are unlocked
* Clearly identifiable on the front driveway or garden
* Only present the items booked for collection – other items not pre\-booked will be left
* Pets are secured (collections may not take place where there is dog waste, or similar, or obstructing access to or around the items.

**Important** \- Crews will not enter your property to remove items.

### How do I book a bulky waste collection?

* [Book a bulky waste collection online](https://wigan.zipporah.co.uk/Waste/BulkyWaste).

Please note, you cannot change or amend your booking online. You must contact [bulkywaste@wigan.gov.uk](mailto:bulkywaste@wigan.gov.uk) to make any changes.

### What we will collect

* [Household](#tab-1)
* [Garden](#tab-2)
* [Appliances](#tab-3)

* Armchairs, sofas, pouffes
* Wardrobes (not dismantled)
* Bed bases, frames, mattresses, futons, sofa beds, headboards, cots
* Sideboards, cabinets
* Tables, chairs
* Bureaus, desks
* Bookcases
* Blanket box
* Chest of drawers, dressing tables
* Hi\-fi units, TV stands/brackets
* Carpets, underlay, lino
* Ironing boards
* Suitcases
* Children's toys, car seats
* Bikes, exercise bikes, treadmills
* Step ladders
* Blinds
* Framed mirrors

* Lawnmowers, strimmers
* Garden furniture, sun loungers
* BBQs (no gas bottles)
* Wheelbarrows

* Cookers, ovens, hobs
* Freezers, fridges (Please ensure all food is removed)
* Microwaves
* Dishwashers
* Washing machines, dryers
* Computers (all parts), monitors
* Lawnmowers, strimmers
* Televisions, radios
* Small electrical items eg hairdryers, irons etc
* Free standing heaters

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

### Items we won't collect

These items can be taken to your local [waste and recycling centre](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Waste-and-Recycling-Centres.aspx "Waste and Recycling Centres") instead.

* [Household](#tab-a "Household - items we won't collect")
* [Garden](#tab-b "Garden - items we won't collect")
* [Appliances](#tab-c "Appliances - items we won't collect")
* [Hazardous](#tab-d "Hazardous - items we won't collect")
* [Miscellaneous](#tab-e "Miscellaneous - items we won't collect")

* Any black bags of rubbish
* Any normal household waste
* Bathroom suite
* Bricks
* Doors (internal and external)
* Fire surrounds
* Fires
* Fish tanks
* Fluorescent tubes
* Glass
* Kitchen unit
* Ladders
* Piano
* Radiators/heaters
* Rubble
* Tiles
* Window frames
* Wood (including shelving)
* Wood flooring
* Worktops

* Any garden rubbish
* Fence panels
* Garage doors
* Gates (wooden and iron)
* Sheds
* Soil
* Trees

* None

* Gas bottles
* Hazardous chemicals (oils, paint tins, asbestos)

* Car parts

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

Browser does not support script.

Try to keep items clean and dry so they can be re\-used or recycled.

**Please note:**  [clinical waste](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Clinical-waste.aspx "Clinical Waste") and [trade waste](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Trade-waste.aspx "Trade Waste") will not be collected.

## Private waste collectors

If you decide to use a private waste collector, remember to:

* Ask to see their waste carriers licence
* Get a receipt to confirm:
	+ What they’ve taken
	+ Where it will be disposed of
	+ Payment made
* Make a note of the vehicle registration

[Find a licenced waste carrier near you (external link)](https://environment.data.gov.uk/public-register/view/search-waste-carriers-brokers).

If you give your waste to someone who is not a licenced waste carrier and it is dumped, you could be fined up to £50,000, just as if you fly\-tipped it yourself.

## Top tasks

### Top Task

1. [Book a bulky waste collection](https://wigan.zipporah.co.uk/Waste/BulkyWaste "Go to the Book a bulky waste collection page")
2. [Cancel your bulky waste collection](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Forms/Cancel-bulky-waste-collection.aspx "Go to the Cancel your bulky waste collection page")
3. [Bulky waste FAQs](/Resident/Bins-Recycling/Bulky-waste-FAQs.aspx "Go to the Bulky waste FAQs page")

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Resident](/Resident/index.aspx "Go to Resident from here")/[Benefits and grants](/Resident/Benefit-Grants/Benefit-Grants.aspx "Go to Benefits and grants from here")/Council Tax Reduction

# Council Tax Reduction

The Council Tax Reduction scheme replaces the previous Council Tax Benefit scheme.

## Who can apply for Council Tax Reduction?

To apply for Council Tax Reduction you must be a person whose name is on the Council Tax bill.

You may qualify if you are:

* On Universal Credit, Income Support, Jobseeker's Allowance or Employment and Support Allowance
* On Pension Credit, Guaranteed Credit and in some cases Savings Credit
* Working and on low pay (including people who are self employed)
* On a low income. For example, you might only get a retirement pension or be getting social security benefits, like Incapacity Benefit.

## How much can I get?

Depending on the household income and savings:

* Pensioner households and households with children under 5 years of age may be able to get a reduction of up to 100% of their bill
* Working age household with no children under 5 may be able to get a reduction of up to 80% of their bill.

## How to apply

You must apply directly to us. You can only get Council Tax Reduction from the date we receive your application.

* [Apply for Council Tax Reduction](https://finforms.wigan.gov.uk/Viewer-VicForms.asp?user=anon&Form=Wigan%20HBCTR%20Claim%20Form%20(2.0).wdf "Apply for Housing Benefit and/or Council Tax reduction")

You need to tell us straight away if you are receiving a Council Tax Reduction and you have a [change in circumstances](https://finforms.wigan.gov.uk/Viewer-VicForms.asp?user=anon&Form=Wigan%20Change%20of%20Circumstances%20(1.4).wdf "Change of circumstances").

We are unable to offer backdated support, entitlement to Council Tax Reduction will only begin from the day we actually receive a valid claim.

* See the full [Council Tax Reduction scheme](/Docs/PDF/Resident/Council-Tax/Council-Tax-Reduction-scheme.pdf "Council Tax Reduction scheme") document.

Please note: If, after assessing your claim, we find you qualify for a reduction, you will receive a revised bill.  However, if you do not qualify we will not contact you and your bill will remain the same.

## Disputes and appeals

If you do not agree with a decision we have made regarding your Council Tax Reduction application then you have the right to ask us to look at the decision again or appeal.

* [Council Tax Reduction \- disputes and appeals](/Resident/Council-Tax/Discounts-reductions-and-exemptions/Appeals.aspx "Council Tax Reduction - Disputes and appeals").

## Discretionary Reduction

If you’re in a difficult financial situation, you may be entitled to a Discretionary Council Tax Reduction. The council covers the full cost of this, therefore applications will be considered against the needs of all local tax payers.

* [See further information on how to apply for Discretionary Council Tax Reduction](/Resident/Council-Tax/Discretionary-Reduction/Discretionary-Council-Tax-Reduction.aspx "Discretionary Council Tax Reduction").

## Top tasks

### Apply for It

1. [Apply for Council Tax Reduction](https://finforms.wigan.gov.uk/Viewer-VicForms.asp?user=anon&Form=Wigan%20HBCTR%20Claim%20Form%20(2.0).wdf "Go to the Apply for Council Tax Reduction page")
### Report it

1. [Report a change](/Resident/Benefit-Grants/Report-a-change.aspx "Go to the Report a change page")

# A\-Z

## [Early Help and Prevention Strategy](/Business/Professionals/Early-Help/Early-Help-policies-and-strategies/Early-Help-Policies-and-Procedures.aspx "Early Help and Prevention Strategy")

 Early Help and Prevention Policy

## [Early Help digital offer for staff and partners](/Business/Professionals/Early-Help/Index.aspx "Early Help digital offer for staff and partners")

 The digital offer for staff and partners will bring all elements of early help together in one place in an online space so that materials are easily accessible for staff and partners.

## [Early Help Research and Principles](/Business/Professionals/Early-Help/Early-Help-policies-and-strategies/Early-Help-Research-and-Principles.aspx "Early Help Research and Principles")

 Early Help Research and Principles

## [Early Intervention \- Children's Services](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Children-and-young-people/Early-Intervention-Childrens-Services.aspx "Early Intervention - Children's Services")

 The Early Intervention service supports both adults and children with disabilities and their families.

## [Early Years](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Children-and-young-people/Health-and-wellbeing/Early-Years.aspx "Early Years")

 Face to face antenatal education workshops are now available across the borough. These sessions are delivered collaboratively across our midwifery service, health visiting teams, Be Well and Start Well Family Centres.

## [Early years music and wellbeing](/Resident/Education/Wigan-Music-Service/Early-years-music-and-wellbeing.aspx "Early years music and wellbeing")

 Early years music and wellbeing

## [e\-books, audio books and e\-magazines](/Resident/Libraries/eMagazines.aspx "e-books, audio books and e-magazines")

 Read full digital copies of your favourite magazines for free and find out where to get free ebooks.

## [Education and Caring for Children](/Resident/Jobs-Careers/Adult-Learning/Education-and-Caring-for-Children.aspx "Education and Caring for Children")

 Working with children and young people is a rewarding career that can go in a number of directions. We provide a range of introductory and Level 2 courses which can lead into a roles in this sector.

## [Education and families](/Resident/Education/Education.aspx "Education and families")

 Information on educational support, schools, alternative education and more.

## [Education Business Intelligence Unit (EBIU)](/Business/School-services/Index.aspx "Education Business Intelligence Unit (EBIU)")

 What the EBIU do, the services we offer and how to log in to access support.

## [Educational psychology](/Resident/Education/Educational-support/Education-Psychology.aspx "Educational psychology")

 Advice and support for parents to help young people progress in education, positive mental health, personal and social development.

## [Election results](/Council/Voting-and-Elections/Election-results.aspx "Election results")

 Election results from previous years.

## [Elections](/Council/Voting-and-Elections/Elections.aspx "Elections")

 Local, by\-elections, parish, UK, European, and police and crime commissioner elections.

## [Emerging Plans](/Resident/Planning-and-Building-Control/Planning/Policies-and-Guidance/Emerging-Plans.aspx "Emerging Plans")

 Emerging Plans

## [Empty homes](/Business/Property-and-Land/Empty-Homes.aspx "Empty homes")

 We can offer you help and support to bring your empty home back to life.

## [Empty Homes Review](/Resident/Council-Tax/Empty-Homes-Review.aspx "Empty Homes Review")

 In support of the government's initiative to tackle the shortfall in national housing and to ensure our council tax data is accurate, we are undertaking a review of our empty residential properties.

## [Energy Efficiency Standards](/Business/Property-and-Land/Private-Landlords/MEES.aspx "Energy Efficiency Standards")

 Since 1 April 2020 all domestic private rented properties must have an Energy Performance Certificate (EPC) of at least band E.

## [Environmental community groups](/Council/The-Deal/Volunteering/Environment/Friends-of-groups.aspx "Environmental community groups")

 'Friends of' and 'In Bloom' groups need your help to keep our parks and green spaces maintained for everyone to enjoy.

## [Environmental crime](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Environmental-crime.aspx "Environmental crime")

 Environmental crime can be fly\-tipping, fly posting, dog fouling and abandoned cars, and if you are prosecuted for any of these then you will receive a fixed penalty notice.

## [Environmental health for businesses](/Business/Environmental-Health/index.aspx "Environmental health for businesses")

 Food hygiene and safety for businesses, pollution and private water supplies, and pest control guidance.

## [Environmental problems](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Environmental-Problems.aspx "Environmental problems")

 Pests, land, noise and air pollution, dog control and food hygiene standards.

## [Equality and Diversity](/Council/Strategies-Plans-and-Policies/Equality-and-Diversity/Index.aspx "Equality and Diversity")

 Read our policies and priorities on equality, diversity and cohesion in Wigan Borough.

## [Equipment and adaptations](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Adults/Your-independence/equipment-and-adaptations.aspx "Equipment and adaptations")

 Specialist equipment and home adaptations to help you live independently.

## [Ethical Lettings Agency (ELA)](/Business/Property-and-Land/Private-Landlords/Ethical-lettings-agency.aspx "Ethical Lettings Agency (ELA)")

 Find out about the Council's Ethical Lettings Agency for local landlords, investors and developers.

## [Events on the highway](/Resident/Parking-Roads-Travel/Roads/Events-on-the-highway.aspx "Events on the highway")

 Apply to hold an event on the public highway, such as parades or walking days.

## [Eviction, harassment and illegal eviction](/Resident/Housing/Private-Housing/Harassment-and-illegal-eviction.aspx "Eviction, harassment and illegal eviction")

 Find out what you can do if your landlord is harassing you or forcing you to leave your home.

## [Evidence based Assessment Tools that underpin the Early Help Assessment](/Business/Professionals/Early-Help/Early-Help-policies-and-strategies/Evidence-based-Assessment.aspx "Evidence based Assessment Tools that underpin the Early Help Assessment")

 Evidence based Assessment Tools that underpin the Early Help Assessment

## [Excavation of the highway](/Business/Licensing-Permits-Registrations/Buildings-Highways/Excavation-of-the-highway.aspx "Excavation of the highway")

 If you intend to dig into a public road, you will need to apply for a Section 50 licence.

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Resident](/Resident/index.aspx "Go to Resident from here")/[Crime and emergencies](/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/Crime-and-emergencies.aspx "Go to Crime and emergencies from here")/Emergency contacts

# Emergency contacts

If an emergency happens in the borough you can get the latest updates \- [follow us on X (formally Twitter)](https://twitter.com/wigancouncil "Twitter-Wigan-Council")

Council contacts
| Contact | Number |
| --- | --- |
| **Council out of hours emergencies** For genuine emergencies concerning drainage, flooding, street lighting, building and electrical repairs, highways. | 01942 404040 |
| **Emergency repairs to council houses** | 01942 489005 |
| **Adult social care** | 01942 828777 |
| **Childrens social care** | 01942 828300 |

National emergency contacts
| Contact | Number |
| --- | --- |
| **Fire, police, ambulance emergencies** | 999 or 112 |
| **Greater Manchester Police** | 0161 872 5050 |
| **Gas emergencies (National Grid)** | 0800 111999 |
| **Electricity emergencies (Electricity North West)** | 0800 195 4141 |
| To report power cuts or damage to power lines or substations | 105 |
| **Water emergencies (United Utilities)** |  |
| No water supply or discoloured water | 0345 672 3723 |
| Problems with drains and sewers | 0845 602 0406 |
| Pollution | 0800 015 1230 |
| Leaks | 0800 330033 |

To assist the emergency services to find your medical information and contacts you can use the national 'Message in a bottle' scheme.

[Home](/index.aspx "Go to Home from here")/[Resident](/Resident/index.aspx "Go to Resident from here")/[Jobs, careers and skills](/Resident/Jobs-Careers/index.aspx "Go to Jobs, careers and skills from here")/Search for a job

# Search for a job

We’ve put together a range useful websites, resources and support services to help you with your job search.

## Help to find employment

* [Wigan Council vacancies and local government roles across Greater Manchester (external link)](https://www.greater.jobs/)
* [EmployGM for the latest job vacancies in Greater Manchester as well as tailored support to help bridge any skills gaps (external link)](https://employgm.org/)
* [NHS jobs (external link)](https://www.jobs.nhs.uk/)
* [Indeed Jobs (external link)](https://uk.indeed.com/ "Indeed UK")
* [Total Jobs (external link)](https://www.totaljobs.com/)
* [Reed Jobs (external link)](https://www.reed.co.uk/jobs)
* [Find a Job (GOV.UK) (external link)](https://findajob.dwp.gov.uk/)
* [CV Library Jobs (external link)](https://www.cv-library.co.uk/)
* [Jobsite (external link)](https://www.jobsite.co.uk/)
* [Monster jobs (external link)](https://www.monster.co.uk/jobs/)
* [Fish 4 Jobs (external link)](https://www.fish4.co.uk/)
* [Smart Works Greater Manchester for women (external link)](https://greatermanchester.smartworks.org.uk/) \- Personalised styling service with full free outfit for the interview which is their to keep. Plus an hour training on interview skills and techniques. Visit the Smart Works website to make an appointment.

### Department for Work and Pensions (DWP)

DWP have a range of help available to jobseekers including essential advice about which sectors are recruiting now, transferable skills and how to secure a new role. ­

* [Job help from Jobcentre Plus (external link)](https://jobhelp.campaign.gov.uk/) \- Finding a job and developing skills
* [Find a Job (GOV.UK) for job seekers (external link)](https://findajob.dwp.gov.uk/)
* [Find a Job (GOV.UK) for employers to advertise opportunities (external link)](https://findajob.dwp.gov.uk/sign-in?employer=1).

## Get help with your application

You can access support when applying for all jobs through the National Careers Service.

Qualified career advisers offer telephone appointments tailored to suit your personal circumstances and can cover the following:

* Securing employment
* CV writing and interview techniques
* Returning to work after a break.

To get support visit the [National Careers Service website (external link)](https://nationalcareers.service.gov.uk/) or call 0161 393 6473\.

Displaying 1 to 25 of 25

## [Fair cost of care](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Adults/Fair-cost-of-care.aspx "Fair cost of care")

 Government's Fair Cost of Care guidance, the Council has carried out a cost of care exercise with care providers to further understand the cost of providing care at home and in care homes within the Borough

## [Family history](/Resident/Museums-archives/Wigan-Archives/Collections/Family-history.aspx "Family history")

 Local and family history collections including books, pamphlets, local newspapers, maps, census and parish registers.

## [Family history](/Resident/Museums-archives/Wigan-Archives/Collections/Family-history.aspx "Family history")

 Local and family history collections including books, pamphlets, local newspapers, maps, census and parish registers.

## [Family Hubs](/Resident/Education/Family-Hubs/index.aspx "Family Hubs")

 Family Hubs are a new way of bringing together all the support a family may need, from pregnancy through to young people turning 19 (or 25 if they have a Special Educational need or disability (SEND).

## [Family Information Service](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Children-and-young-people/Childcare/Family-Information-Service.aspx "Family Information Service")

 The Family Information Service provides information to families about help with the cost of childcare, eligibility and access to government funded early education and finding childcare services in your area. We also offer business support to childcare settings and advice on setting up a childcare service.

## [Feedback, Complaints and Compliments](/Resident/Jobs-Careers/Adult-Learning/Feedback-Complaints-and-Compliments.aspx "Feedback, Complaints and Compliments")

 We want to hear your ideas and feedback about what we are doing well. Also, if there is anything we need to improve please tell us about it so that we can offer you the best possible experience.

## [Filming in Wigan Borough](/Council/Contact-us/Filming-in-Wigan-Borough.aspx "Filming in Wigan Borough")

 Wigan Council are a film\-friendly local authority who are members of the Filming in England Partnership.

## [Financial plan (Council budget)](/Council/Performance-and-Spending/Financial-Plan.aspx "Financial plan (Council budget)")

 The budget that the council has agreed for the financial year.

## [Find a care home](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Adults/Community-support/Residential-care/Find-a-care-home.aspx "Find a care home")

 Search the Care Quality Commission directory for a care home in the borough.

## [Find a home](/Resident/Housing/Council-homes/Find-a-home/index.aspx "Find a home")

 Search and apply for a home, find out your options, getting on the housing register, leaving accommodation and more.

## [Find your ward or polling district](https://apps.wigan.gov.uk/MyNeighbourhood/ "Find your ward or polling district")

 Find out what ward you live in and polling district.

## [First homes](/Resident/Housing/Buying/First-Homes.aspx "First homes")

 First homes is a new scheme which is designed to help local first time buyers and key works onto the property ladder. The homes offered through this scheme will be discounted by a minimum of 30% compared to market value. The homes purchased under this scheme will remain first homes forever. This means that generations of new buyers will continue to benefit from this scheme every time the property is sold.

## [Fixed Penalty Notices](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/FPN.aspx "Fixed Penalty Notices")

 This is a fine issued for a criminal offence including parking offences, anti\-social behaviour and environmental crime.

## [Flooding and drainage](/Resident/Crime-Emergencies/Flooding/Index.aspx "Flooding and drainage")

 Preparing for a flood, managing flood risk, who is responsible for rivers, drains and sewers and reporting a flooding issue.

## [Fly tipping](/Resident/Environmental-Problems/Rubbish-and-Litter/Fly-tipping.aspx "Fly tipping")

 How to report fly tipping around the borough.

## [Food hygiene and safety](/Business/Environmental-Health/Food-Hygiene-and-Safety/index.aspx "Food hygiene and safety")

 Food hygiene ratings, registering a food premises, food hygiene inspections, report a complaint and more.

## [Forward plans](https://democracy.wigan.gov.uk/mgListPlans.aspx?RPId=130&RD=0 "Forward plans")

 Notice of every key decision which is due to be taken in the next 28 days.

## [Fostering](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Children-and-young-people/Fostering/Fostering.aspx "Fostering")

 Find out who can foster, what your options are and how to apply to become one.

## [Free early education and childcare for 3 and 4 year olds](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Children-and-young-people/Childcare/Free-childcare-3-and-4-year-olds.aspx "Free early education and childcare for 3 and 4 year olds")

 All 3 and 4 year old children are entitled to free early education and childcare for 15 hours per week for 38 weeks a year.

## [Free school meals, pupil premium, and EYPP](/Resident/Benefit-Grants/Free-school-meals.aspx "Free school meals, pupil premium, and EYPP")

 Parents who are on low income can apply for free school meals for their children.

## [Freedom of Information](/Council/DataProtection-FOI-Stats/index.aspx "Freedom of Information")

 An overview of Data Protection and Freedom of Information.

## [Frozen pipes and heating issues](/Resident/Housing/Council-homes/Repairs/Frozen-pipes-heating-issues.aspx "Frozen pipes and heating issues")

 Tips on how to resolve some issues with frozen pipes and boiler issues which may impact in loss of hot water and heating.

## [Functional Skills: English and Maths](/Resident/Jobs-Careers/Adult-Learning/Functional-Skills-English-and-Maths.aspx "Functional Skills: English and Maths")

 English and Maths are essential skills to secure a new job, move on to a further education course, or even to help your child at home with their school work.

## [Funded Early Education and Childcare for 2 year olds](/Resident/Health-Social-Care/Children-and-young-people/Childcare/Free-childcare-2-year-olds.aspx "Funded Early Education and Childcare for 2 year olds")

 Some children who are aged two years of age can access 15 hours of free early education and childcare.

## [Funding for business](/Business/Business-Support/Funding/Index.aspx "Funding for business")

 Get access to the latest funding opportunities, including our Business Booster and Growth Accelerator.

Displaying 1 to 25 of 25
